What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: in-depth experience with gene-editing method CRISPR and designing an experiment
I gained an understanding of how to conduct biostatistical research.
I learned how to design CRISPR experiments and assays, as well as how to write a scientific paper.
I gained the useful skills of organizing and writing a research paper. Additionally, I was given insight in the tools used by biologists in the field of genetics and cellular biology.

This course did an amazing job of adapting to a virtual lab setting, focusing on a semester-long molecular biology bioinformatics project. This project exposed us to existing and emerging bioinformatics techniques, as well as challenged us to apply knowledge we gained in other biology courses such as the molecular biology underlying gene regulation, editing, and key pathways.
Using SeqBuilder Pro, improved understanding of genetics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: good class, very confusing, TAs were not always helpful and late with their feedback

This class taught us information that is extremely relevant to anyone who wants to do research in the biological sciences. However, it was often very long and somewhat disorganized, which honestly made it hard to stay awake at points. On the bright side, the TAs were very helpful in giving feedback, and Dr. Moreno always answered any questions we had.

Dr. Moreno is the strength of this course. She is great. Even with online class, she found an interesting project with the tomato genome that taught us all so much in a hands-on way. I've never taken a class that left me this prepared for the real-world, and it was perfect for anyone looking to do research especially in genetics. I don't want this to be a bad reflection on the teaching staff, but this class was also hugely stressful. It felt like we were learning how to do piece by piece as they came and as a class, we weren't really let in on the full picture of what we were doing until the very end. 

I hate to be the student who brings up grading, but we did not receive a single piece of graded work until May 5th. My canvas grades page said 'N/A' until the very last week of classes. After that, the staff provided great feedback that was incredibly helpful for writing the final draft. They made themselves available to meet and answer questions, but I would be remiss to not mention that for most of the semester we all felt like we were in some kind of limbo not knowing where we stood grade-wise.

The course was very well-structured. The lectures were helpful and the office hours, alongside emails were helpful in clarifying the assignments. One small weakness would be that sometimes the assignments were slightly confusing, but usually an email to Professor Moreno would clear up the confusion.

I think Dr. Moreno did an incredible job of creating a course experience that replicated the in-person experience as much as possible. Organization, clarity, and availability were certainly strengths.
Great learning and instruction

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A

The virtual format was very well-suited for the students, but sometimes the programs used were a bit confusing. However, the course effectively implemented the techniques and allowed students to learn the material very well.
Difficult to be as engaged in virtual format

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes, if it is in person
I would recommend this class to a student who is interested in conducting bioinformatics research.

Even despite some of the organizational challenges, I do recommend this course. I think Covid caused most of the issues, so in a normal semester it would be a great class to prepare anyone to do research or just learn from Dr. Moreno.

I would recommend this course to another student as it provides priceless research knowledge. At the beginning, it may seem intimidating, but by the end, you will be proud of the paper that you wrote!

I would recommend this course. Even though the format will likely change as we return to in-person learning, Dr. Moreno genuinely cares about students understanding and benefitting from material, which makes for a tremendous course experience.
Yes if really interested in learning more about molecular biology
